New Records: The Mets became the first team to not strike out in a postseason game since the Angels in Game 2 of the 2002 World Series against San Francisco.
Key Match Events: Pete Alonso hit a three-run homer in the first inning to set the tone for the game.
Alonso also scored four runs and drew a leadoff walk in the third inning.
Andy Pages homered twice and drove in four runs for the Dodgers.
Mookie Betts went deep for the second consecutive game, helping Los Angeles cut an eight-run deficit to 10-6.
Pre-Game Insights: The Mets were aware it could be the last home game for Alonso at Citi Field, and the sellout crowd of 43,841 chanted his name when he batted in the eighth.
Post-Match Reflections: Alonso said it's so special to have the crowd's support and that it's like storybook-type stuff.
Mets manager Carlos Mendoza said they needed that win to extend their season and that Alonso set the tone in the first inning.
Edwin DÃ­az said they come from a lot of adversity and that they can beat the Dodgers.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers will go with another bullpen game because of a thin rotation decimated by injuries.
The Mets will start Sean Manaea in Game 6 on Sunday, while the Dodgers will try to determine whether to start Freddie Freeman due to his badly sprained right ankle.
Others: The game was played at Citi Field in front of a sellout crowd of 43,841.
The Mets trimmed their series deficit to 3-2 and sent the best-of-seven NLCS back to Los Angeles for Game 6 on Sunday.
